title: ASX to fall; Woolworths, CPI ahead
text:
The S &P 500 snapped a four-session win streak. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 20.11 points, or 0.07%, to 27,070.61, the S &P 500 lost 2.56 points, or 0.08%, to 3036.86 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 49.14 points, or 0.59%, to 8276.85

The Fed is expected to pare its key rate range by 25 basis point, the third such cut in what it has called a "mid-cycle adjustment". Investors are keen to see if policymakers will signal a shift to a pause or hint at more cuts.

On Twitter, President Donald Trump, yet again, pressed the Fed to cut rates.

In a note, Bank of America Merrill Lynch said: "In our view, the Fed will likely guide that further moves are possible, depending on the data and incoming information. Others in the market are looking for the statement to signal that the Fed is content with the current policy stance. But, in our view, this would be unnecessarily hawkish given the market is currently pricing in 40% probability of a cut at the December meeting."

Still, BofAML said it expected "the US economic slowdown will force the Fed to cut rates in December" even though the Fed will likely be non-committal about future rate cuts.

"An important split from the last two meetings would be if [Fed chairman Jerome] Powell also acknowledges some slowdown in the economy, noting it is a reason for the cut," BofAML said. "It would imply that the Fed is transitioning back to a more data-dependent policy."

On the local front, corporate news at the top of today's agenda includes a trading update from Woolworths.

As for data, it's time for third-quarter CPI. Here's what TD, NAB and Westpac are expecting.

Advertisement

TD Securities: "We forecast Q3 headline inflation to edge up 0.6%/q (prior 0.4%) on alcohol, food & tobacco, with fuel providing some offset. This takes annual headline CPI to 1.8% from 1.6%. Underlying inflation is expected to remain a touch below 0.4%/q, keeping core inflation ~1.5%/y. However this outcome is unlikely to trigger the RBA to cut next month."

NAB forecasts headline and trimmed mean inflation remained unchanged at 0.4% q/q / 1.6% y/y. "If our forecast for core inflation proves right, the Reserve Bank would likely read the data as continuing to suggest that spare capacity remains in the economy, consistent with below-trend growth and too-high unemployment. Barring a very weak outcome, the Reserve Bank is likely to remain focused on labour market developments as it aims to reach full employment, which should spark a lift in wages growth and inflation."

Westpac is forecasting a 0.6% rise in the September quarter CPI lifting the annual pace to 1.8%yr from 1.6%yr. "Core inflation remains well below the bottom of the RBA target band as moderating housing costs offset modest inflationary pressure elsewhere. Competitive disinflationary pressure in consumer goods is limiting the pass through of the weaker AUD though it is having some impact. Given this we find it hard to envisage core inflation breaking higher any time soon let alone returning to the mid-point of the 2%yr to 3%yr target band."

Today's agenda

Local: CPI third quarter

Overseas data: Euro zone economic confidence October, Business climate October, Consumer confidence October; US ADP employment report October, GDP third quarter annualised, Federal Reserve policy decision at 5am AEDT Thursday

Market highlights

ASX futures down 23 points or 0.3% to 6700 near 7.45am AEDT

Advertisement

AUD +0.4% to 68.64 US cents

Sterling flat at $US1.2863

On Wall St near 4pm: Dow -0.1% S &P 500 -0.1% Nasdaq -0.6%

In New York: BHP -0.3% Rio +0.1% Atlassian +1.3%

In Europe: Stoxx 50 -0.1% FTSE -0.3% CAC +0.2% DAX flat

Nikkei 225 futures -0.1%

Spot gold -0.3% to $US1488.74 an ounce at 1pm New York time

Brent crude +0.6% to $US61.93 a barrel

US oil +0.1% to $US55.84 a barrel

Iron ore -1.5% to $US86.64 a tonne

Dalian iron ore -0.9% to 617 yuan

LME aluminium +1% to $US1754 a tonne

LME copper bid up 0.3% to $US5927 a tonne

2-year yield: US 1.64% Australia 0.81%

5-year yield: US 1.66% Australia 0.85%

10-year yield: US 1.83% Australia 1.18% Germany -0.35%

10-year US/Australia yield gap near 7.45am AEDT: 65 basis points

From today's Financial Review

Huang Xiangmo's $135m planning windfall: The Chinese billionaire stands to make $135 million profit from a Sydney planning decision, thanks to a local councillor who failed to declare a $4 million link to the developer.

Chanticleer: The science that shows it's hard to beat the market: As the hunt for yield gets harder, new work from Melbourne-based Professor Peter Bossaerts shows why index investing is a good bet.

Fundies warn Lowe that low rates are backfiring: "If low interest rates and ease of borrowing were the foundation of strong growth, surely Japan and Europe would now be growing very strongly," Investors Mutual says.

United States

The S &P 500 touched a record high on Tuesday as investors cheered strong earnings from big drug makers Merck and Pfizer, while a disappointing profit from Google parent Alphabet kept the Nasdaq firmly in the red.

Hopes of a US-China trade deal and expectations of another rate cut by the Federal Reserve when it concludes its two-day meeting on Wednesday have kept markets inching higher this week.

Advertisement

Merck and Pfizer both gained after reporting upbeat third-quarter results to help keep the Dow and S &P near the flat line. The healthcare sector, which has been the second-worst performer among the 11 major S &P 500 sectors this year, rose 1.2% as the best performer on the session as Merck gained 3.5% and Pfizer advanced 2.5%.

Shares of Google parent Alphabet, however, lost 2.2% and weighed on the Nasdaq as its quarterly profit missed estimates due to higher costs.

Third-quarter earnings of S &P 500 companies have largely been better than expected, easing some of the concerns over growth which have dogged markets this year, with over 77% of the 236 firms to report so far surpassing profit expectations, according to Refinitiv data.

Tesla's third-quarter revenue tumbled 39% in the United States, its first drop in more than two years, but sales in China and other regions surged, the electric car maker's break down of sales by geography showed.

US sales, which account for the biggest share of the company's total revenue, fell to $US3.13 billion from $US5.13 billion a year earlier.

Sales in China rose 64% to $US699 million and its other segment, which covers the rest of the globe, rose by more than a billion dollars to $US1.83 billion, a regulatory filing showed.

Europe

Fiat Chrysler, Peugeot owner PSA in talks to combine: The Italian-American auto maker may finally have found a merger partner.

Advertisement

Embattled Cuadrilla says gas from second well 'highest quality yet': Green groups say the project is 'dead', but the fracking company half-owned by ASX-listed AJ Lucas is still fighting.

European shares closed lower for the first time in seven sessions on Tuesday, as weak earnings dampened optimism surrounding the US-China trade progress and ahead of an expected interest-rate cut by the US Federal Reserve later this week.

The pan-European STOXX 600 fell 0.2% after scaling a 21-month high in the previous session, tracking record gains for Wall Street's S &P 500 index; the S &P 500 touched a record high overnight before slipping modestly lower.

"The markets are at new highs in Europe and in the US and that is also something that could be pushing investors to take some profit," said Roland Kaloyan, head of European equity strategy at Société Générale.

Finnish paper firm Stora Enso's slumped 5.1% as its quarterly profit dropped and it warned of global political uncertainties.

Peers Mondi and Smurfit Kappa also fell following the results.

Telecom stocks lost 1.7%, the most among the major European sub-sectors, hurt by a 2.6% slide in shares of Orange .

Asia

Advertisement

Japanese stocks rose to the highest in more than a year on Tuesday, as negotiators from the United States and China moved a step closer to scaling back their bruising trade war in a boost to the prospects for corporate earnings.

The benchmark Nikkei benchmark share average ended up 0.5% at 22,974.13. It earlier rose to 23,008.43, the highest since October 11, 2018. So far it is up 14.3% for the year.

In contrast, Hong Kong shares closed lower, pulling back from six-month highs recorded a day earlier, as investors took profits.

The Hang Seng index closed 104.50 points down or 0.4% at 26,786.76. The Hang Seng China Enterprises index fell 0.2% to 10,547.

The sub-index of the Hang Seng tracking energy shares dipped 0.5%, the financial sector ended 0.5% lower and the property sector rose 0.1%. The IT sector, which had lifted the Hang Seng index to its highest close in six weeks on Monday, dipped 1.5%.

Hong Kong's embattled leader Carrie Lam said on Tuesday she expects the Asian financial hub to record negative economic growth for the full 2019 year, as the city grapples with five months of often violent anti-government protests.

Currencies

President Donald Trump launched a fresh attack on the Federal Reserve on Tuesday (Wednesday AEDT), saying it needed to follow other nations with negative interest rates, as officials opened a two-day meeting that was expected to end with a rate cut.

Advertisement

"The Fed doesn’t have a clue! We have unlimited potential, only held back by the Federal Reserve," Trump wrote on Twitter.

Lowe rejects Costello and Keating's view on rate cuts: Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe has repudiated former treasurers Paul Keating and Peter Costello's view that monetary policy has "run its race" and is no longer effective.

RBA urges boards to cut hurdle rates: Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe has pressured business and government to wake up to the opportunity of cheaper credit by lowering high return hurdles and starting to invest.

Central banks are losing the inflation battle: The RBA is set for another unwelcome reminder that it's losing the battle to restore price growth to the target band.

The RBA cannot lose control of the inflation narrative: In the twilight of the central banking gods, monetary policy is reduced to shadow boxing.

Commodities

Forrest takes swipe at BHP, Rio over customer emissions claims: The Fortescue chairman says the iron ore miner will control what it can control and not chase media "sugar hits" with claims about reducing scope 3 emissions.

Saudi Aramco shares to start trading in December: A final price for the stock will be set December 4, with trading to start a week later on the Riyadh-based Tadawul stock market, Al-Arabiya reported.

Advertisement

China's three biggest commodities exchanges said on Tuesday they would end their practice of double-counting trades from January 1, 2020 and report on a single-count basis instead to help them converge with international standards.

The Shanghai Futures Exchange (ShFE), known for its base metal contracts, the Dalian Commodity Exchange (DCE), home to China's iron ore futures, and the Zhengzhou Commodity Exchange, which trades sugar and cotton, announced the switch in separate statements.

Iron ore futures in Dalian and Singapore fell on Tuesday on worries about demand for the steelmaking raw material in China.

Rising inventory of imported iron ore at Chinese ports, which scaled a six-month peak of 134.1 million tonnes last week, based on the latest data from SteelHome consultancy, added to the downward pressure.

Dalian Commodity Exchange's most-traded iron ore contract, with January 2020 expiry, ended down 1.7% at 622 yuan ($US88.14) a tonne, pulling back after touching its highest in nearly two weeks on Monday.

On the Singapore Exchange, January 2020 iron ore traded at as low as $US78.70 a tonne, while the front-month December contract was down 0.5% at $US81.32 in afternoon trade.

"Investors remained cautious amid subdued Chinese steel margins and construction demand," ANZ Research analysts said in a note.

Australian sharemarket

Advertisement

Australian shares finished the day slightly higher on Tuesday, after a fall in energy and utilities weighed down a strong performance from the IT sector in particular.

Marking the seventh consecutive day of gains for the market, the S &P/ASX 200 Index advanced 4.7 points, or 0.07 per cent, to 6745.4.

Street Talk

Service Stream dials up interest in Lendlease's Services

Brokers pitch more than seven reasons to buy Elanor fund

PIMCO lines up brokers for ASX-listed fund
description: Australian shares are poised to open lower, following cautious trading overseas, as investors await the Federal Reserve's US interest rate outlook.
